title.narrative: Large Scale Land Based Inv. Amuria

description.narrative: Eastern and Southern African Farmers Forum-Uganda (ESAFF-Uganda) is part of a regional small scale farmers# coalition established in 2002 during the World Summit for Sustainable Development (WSSD) in Johannesburg to bring together small scale farmers, pastoralists and traditional fisher folks at different levels into a social movements with a common aspirations and ensure learning <(>&<)> linkages. ESAFF- Uganda is a partner implementing Right to Food in Uganda with the role of working with small scale farmers, consortium members of R2F project and other like-minded organizations to push for the recognition of small scale farmers# voices by organizing farmers and support their participation in high level lobby meetings, campaigns, dialogues and policy meetings. ESAFF Uganda and Oxfam In Uganda piloted the Oxfam Meaningful Community Engagement tools in Large Scale Land Based Investments in Agriculture (MECoT- LSLBI) in Amuru district in 2017, with funding from Oxfam Pan African Team. Experience of piloting the LSLBI tools in agriculture in Amuru district coupled with the trend of land dispossession from small scale farmers by private and public large-scale land investors necessitate empowering communities with practical-innovative tools and approaches that help to position them to engage meaningfully throughout the investment processes and stages for a win-win engagement. Above all, the land rights of the poor need to be protected first by the landowners themselves and other concerned stakeholders, and thisis the rationale of scaling up the LSLBI tools inAmuria.

participating-org.narrative:
In 2002, Participatory Ecological Land Use Management (PELUM) Association, a regional network, conceived an exciting idea of a Small Farmers Convergence (SFC) alongside the World Summit on Sustainable Agriculture in Johannesburg. The main aim of the convergence was to make small farmers, pastoralists and fisher folk, who are central to sustainable natural resource management and development,more visible The Small Farmers Convergence was rated a success in terms of increased visibility of farmers, representation on the CSO International Steering Group, exposure and capacity building of the farmers but most important was the identity and solidarity that developed amongst the farmers. The 300 delegates of the Small Farmer Convergence, decided to set up a Regional Forum of Small-scale farmers, pastoralists and traditional fisher folks which was called the East and Southern African Farmers Forum (ESAFF). The rationale for the Regional Forum was to consolidate the development of a farmer movement and build on common aspirations, learning andlinkages made during the SFC.
Formation stage-after the inception of ESAFF Uganda, leadership was elected and then farmers were mobilised in the 14 districts. Every district then elected a committee that was to runthe activities of ESAFF at the grass root level.ESAFF Uganda then developed its constitution, articles of association and Memorandum of association which documents were later usedto register it. The constitution does not discriminate against women or men or youth, leadership is open to all as long as one has the ability to lead. The ESAFF national board is comprised mainly of women with the ratio of men: women being 2:5. The institution right now is in the process of strengthening its membership at the grassroots and the secretariat too. ESAFGF Uganda has not receivedfunding from Oxfam Novib before. However, Oxfam Great Britain has funded a pilot (1.1.08-31.12.08) to increase participation of ssfin budgeting processes.
